text: it's a really was a very finely balanced
decision and my concern was not just
about making sure we had the evidence
which we did but making sure that we
also took into account what the
complainants wanted hence why I
contacted the inquiry I don't think it's
a decision that I should resign over
it's one that I took very carefully and
with the victims at the heart of that
that's why we talked about the victims
right to review and I encourage them to
do that that's where we are today did
you take the advice of your principal
legal adviser from within the CPS Neil
Moore did you agree with what he told
you I made my own decision it was my
decision there were lots of people who
disagreed with him I'm not saying that
I'm saying there are lots of people it
doesn't actually matter because it was
my decision at the end of the day and
there were lots of things that I took
into account so it was my decision at
the end of the day to decide to
prosecute him it's my decision that has
been reviewed and now has been
overturned well that's true but it will
matter to some people because they will
want to know whether you listen to the
principal legal adviser that this
organization employs internally to give
you advice on these big cases and he
played no part in the decision-making it
was my decision alone did you take
advice at that point from independent
external counsel and there had been
earlier advice from external counsel yes
and did you agree with that advice did
you go along with that advice or did you
disagree with it I agreed with possibly
to around the evidential part I did not
agree with the public interest part so
it sounds to me as though this was
absolutely as you say it was your
decision you were advised by your own
principal legal adviser internally you
were advised by an independent legal
adviser from outside the CPS and you
disagreed with some of what they had to
say and some of some of it really
doesn't matter because it was my
decision and it's my decision that's
been reviewed so the basis on which I
did it was looking at the evidence that
was before me looking at all the
different factors that you take into
account in relation to public interest
which will be things like what did the
victims want what was the likely outcome
what was going to happen at court the
severity of the allegations and as
I found it a really difficult decision
for me it was very finely balanced but I
decided not to proceed at that time that
decision has been reviewed and we have
now changed that decisions who we are
prosecuting
